{{Other people|Martin Klein}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Marty Klein | image = Marty Klein 2017.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption =Marty Klein 2017 | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Palo Alto, California]] | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = [[family therapy|Family & Marriage Therapist]]
Certified [[sex therapy|Sex Therapist]] | workplaces = | alma_mater = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[sex education]]
policy analyst | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | spouse = | website = [https://www.martyklein.com/ Marty Klein's ''Sexual Intelligence'' Blog and website] | module = {{Listen | filename = Marty Klein Audio.ogg | title = Marty Klein's voice | type = speech | description = recorded in May 2017 }} }} '''Marty Ralph Klein''' (born 1950) is an American [[sex therapist]], author, educator and [[public policy analyst]]. Klein has spent his career supporting the healthy sexual expression of men, women and couples in a wide range of ways. He is critical of censorship, the concepts of [[sex addiction]] and [[porn addiction]], as well as the [[anti-pornography movement]]. He believes that public policy relating to sexuality should be driven by scientific data rather than emotion, "tradition" or popular but untrue myths. He has been a participant in various state, federal and international court cases dealing with the [[First Amendment]], obscenity, censorship and "harmful to minors" laws. ==Early life== Klein grew up in [[Brooklyn, New York]]. While still in elementary school he began to play the recorder and to collect stamps, interests he has continued throughout his life. Collecting stamps led to a lifelong interest in geography and history. He later wrote on these topics frequently when he began to lecture and travel internationally.{{cite web|title=Marty's Travel Blog |url=https://martystravels.wordpress.com/about/ |accessdate=16 April 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170416225204/https://martystravels.wordpress.com/about/ |archivedate=April 16, 2017 |df= }} After graduating from [[Stuyvesant High School]] in 1967 he attended the [[Stony Brook University|State University of New York at Stony Brook]]. There he developed a passion for sociology and went on to attend PhD programs in sociology at [[Indiana University]] and the [[University of California]].http://www.sexualintelligence.org ==Career== Klein was trained in the doctoral programs of two different branches of sociology: the first was survey research, the use of statistical analysis to gather data about human behavior in order to understand, correlate and predict it; the second was [[ethnomethodology]], which is the study of how people create meaning as a prelude to creating orderly social interactions and predictable social institutions. While at the University of California, Klein worked at the local weekly newspaper the ''[[Santa Barbara Independent|Santa Barbara News & Review]]'', his first job was a writer. In 1976 the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' published his op-ed piece on contraceptive advertising; together these two outlets began his career as a professional writer. First as a volunteer and then as a staff member, Klein worked for the Santa Barbara branch of [[Planned Parenthood]] (1976-1980). While there he became intrigued with the recurring experience of women returning for pregnancy tests multiple times despite being prescribed or given various types of contraception. These women's explanations surprised him: they didn't want to use birth control because they were afraid their partner would think they were a slut, or that they had actually planned to have sex with a stranger they'd just met at a bar. Planned Parenthood then asked him to run a group for the male partners of women coming to the birth control clinic. He also received a grant from the state Office of Family Planning relating to male sexuality. His interest already piqued by his experiences at the clinic, he began his career in human sexuality. {{Cquote|America needs a model of sexual health that is ''sex-positive''.}} ==Sexuality== Klein is best known for promoting changes in personal and social attitudes toward sex and sexuality. He has given several media interviews and written blog posts about his views on topics such sexuality in the media, pornography, and children and sexuality. {{Cquote|When it comes to finding an expert on all things sex, you can't come much closer than Marty Klein. ...you'll learn a lot from reading what he has to say whether you agree with him or not.{{cite web|last1=DiSalvo|first1=David|title=Six Writers Who Know More About Sex Than You Do (So Read Them)|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/daviddisalvo/2012/05/28/six-writers-who-know-more-about-sex-than-you-do-so-read-them/#6c5a0f3f34da|website=Pharma & Healthcare|publisher=Forbes.com|accessdate=5 May 2017}}}} ===Views on sexuality in the media=== Klein has been outspoken about the way sexuality is discussed in media outlets. For example, a 2005 ''[[New York Times]]'' article on the phenomenon of self-help books about sexual positions, sex fantasies and increasingly edgy materials stated that the genre is big business, aimed at women and promoting the idea that "It is a woman's role to ensure that the couple's sex life remains satisfying." Klein disagrees that the promises that these books make about improving sex with oral, anal and fetishistic techniques and information are not what most couples really need to make them happy. "A book called 'How to Get Your Wife to Hug You a Little Bit More' or 'How to Get Your Husband to Slow Down and Caress Your Hair and Love Doing It,' now those are books that would change people's lives," says Klein.{{cite web|last1=La Ferla|first1=Ruth|title=More Sex, Less 'Joy'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/29/fashion/sundaystyles/more-sex-less-joy.html|website=Fashion & Style|publisher=NY Times|accessdate=22 January 2017}} Communication is the key to satisfying relationships; things like new positions or removing pornography from a home without your partner's consent is generally not helpful.{{cite web|last1=Sohn|first1=Amy|title=First Comes Sex Talk With These Renegades of Couples Therapy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/05/fashion/first-comes-sex-talk-with-these-renegades-of-couples-therapy.html?_r=0|website=Fashion & Style|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=28 January 2017}} Klein told the ''Commonwealth Club'' that what most adults want out of sex is a combination of "pleasure and closeness," and he encourages people to pay more attention to these, rather than to performance anxiety or how they look.{{cite web|title=Sexual Intelligence: A New View of Sexual Function & Satisfaction|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=to6cFe6op9s|publisher=The Commonwealth Club of California|accessdate=28 January 2017}} Klein has criticized the mass media for talking about sexuality in what he claims is an exploitative manner. He calls this the "Oprah-ization" factor, where talk shows like ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show|Oprah]]'' and ''[[Dr. Phil]]'' will, for example, put teen prostitutes on stage and talk about how awful it is. What they are really doing, according to Klein, is showing teen girls in skimpy clothing talking about sex, which results in voyeuristic viewers. "If the American media really thought these stories were so terrible it wouldn't give them so much air time ... The key message in American culture is that sex is dangerous. But sex isn't dangerous, bad sexual decision making is dangerous." In an interview with Chip August for ''Personal Life Media'' Klein stated, "I think Oprah has single-handedly launched the victim industry in this country," adding that society is now infantilizing women by saying that they are unable to make decisions for themselves, that they are tricked into drinking at parties, that they can't control whether they get drunk or create circumstances of vulnerability. "It's demeaning to people to say that even though you're an adult, we're not going to hold you accountable for your own decision-making," he says.{{cite web|last1=August|first1=Chip|title=Episode 1: Dr. Marty Klein: "America’s War on Sex: The Attack on Law, Lust, and Liberty"|url=http://podcasts.personallifemedia.com/podcasts/222-sex-love-and-intimacy/episodes/2889-dr-marty-klein-america-s-war-on-sex-the-attack-on-law-lust-and-liberty-|publisher=Personal Life Media|accessdate=23 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=War on Sex|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0hLVnNqAKv4|publisher=Reason.TV|accessdate=28 January 2017}} ===Views on pornography=== Klein has criticized as unproven the theory of "secondary effects", which posits that people involved with various forms of commercial sexual expression (such as escorts, strip clubs or pornography) will inevitably get involved with other, non-sexual illegal activity such as burglary, vandalism, or assault. He states that there is no evidence for this, but the idea appeals intuitively to many people. Thus instead of looking at the actual causal factors of crime, they seek to ban pornography, strip clubs and other outlets to reduce it.{{cite web|last1=Gorman|first1=Melanie|title=War On Sex? An Interview With Dr. Marty Klein|url=https://www.yourtango.com/experts/rachel-kleinman/war-sex-interview-dr-marty-klein-expert|website=Expert Blog|publisher=Your Tango|accessdate=22 January 2017}} On [[20/20]] Klein told host John Stossel that 150 years ago most people got married as soon as they reached puberty, which was about 14 or 15 years old. Now most Americans reach puberty around ages 10–12 but they delay marriage into their late 20s. "Telling people to not have sex is like telling a depressed person to have a nice day and expecting that to lift their depression."{{cite web|last1=Stossel|first1=John|title=Age of Consent|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KDsy72Aqj7U|publisher=20/20|accessdate=28 January 2017}} In December 2016, Klein was a return guest on ''[[The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe]]'' talking about his book ''His Porn, Her Pain: Confronting America's Porn Panic with Honest Talk about Sex''. He explained that he wrote this book in response to [[Broadband]] internet making porn more available - and the accompanying increase in women complaining about their men viewing porn, as well as to help improve sexual literacy of both adults and minors. Host [[Steven Novella]] asked Klein if anti-pornography groups are trying to justify their opposition by citing health concerns or were just confused about the science. Klein responded that both are true. "The junk science is there for anyone who wants to use it," he said, noting that the common claims that pornography leads to various social problems lack evidence to support them, as rates of sexual violence, divorce, teen pregnancy and child molestation have all gone down since Broadband pornography became common. He observed that couples that don't have sex anymore are quicker to fight about pornography rather than have a meaningful conversation about problems in their sexual relationships. [[Cara Santa Maria]] asked if porn leads to unrealistic expectations by men. "Absolutely yes!" Klein answered. "Some people think porn is a documentary, showing real people in real situations... porn is usually unusual bodies, doing unusual things in unusual circumstances." "Pornography leaves out so much that we value in sex. Kissing, hugging ... whispering... because if you watch people hug, after about 2 seconds it gets real boring." In addition, he explained that consumer products based on fantasy are mostly about what people want to see, not necessarily what they want to do or experience, as both men and woman fantasize about things they would not do even if given the chance.{{cite web|title=Podcast #596 - December 10th, 2016|url=https://www.theskepticsguide.org/podcast/sgu/596|publisher=The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe|accessdate=23 January 2017}} ===Views on children and sexuality=== In a 2012 interview with ''Your Tango'', Klein stated that in America, children are raised to have negative feelings about sex and their sexuality. In Europe most beaches are clothing optional, yet in America nudity on beaches is a crime. "When children in the United States grow up learning that their sexuality is bad, when every institution that children have contact with reminds them that their sexuality is bad or dirty or shameful or dangerous — when those kids grow up to be adults, they carry those lessons with them. And one of the things those kids decide when they are adults is that 'if there's something wrong with my sexuality, there must be something wrong with everyone else's sexuality. And, therefore, it's not only my sexuality that I need to repress, it's other people's sexuality that I need to be concerned about, too." This is, Klein says, one of the roots of censorship in America. Further, he has been critical of laws which make it risky for parents to take photos of their children in the bathtub, or for teenagers to take sexual photos of themselves for their own private use. In addition, he has spoken out against the way he sees teens being treated as a sexually repressed minority, such as the criminalization and punishment of teen "sexting," and the deliberate withholding of sexual information and sexual health products from them.{{cite web|last1=Klein|first1=Marty|title="Sexting" Can’t—Repeat, Can’t—Kill Anyone|url=https://www.martyklein.com/sexting-cant-repeat-cant-kill-anyone/|website=MartyKlein.com|accessdate=22 January 2017}} In a 2015 ''New York Times'' interview, Klein was asked how best to talk to children about sex. He responded that it depends on the child, since a younger child will probably not notice the conversation, and older children will need additional information and it is best for parents to respond honestly in a way that reflects their values. A teenager will need to understand what is real and what is fictional entertainment. In all cases, Klein said, it is important to listen, remain calm and make sure the child knows they are not a bad person for having sex questions and that they can ask the parent anything. '"There’s a technical word for the conversations that adults have with their kids when the parents are uncomfortable'" said Klein '"parenting.'"{{cite web|last1=O'Learly|first1=Amy|title=How to Talk to Your Kids About Pornography Parents’ Stories and Expert Advice|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/05/10/garden/porn-intro.html|website=Home and Garden|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=28 January 2017}} Klein has also noted that children are learning about sex despite "anti-sex crusaders" and other societal forces trying to keep it from them: "The truth is children think about sex whether we want them to or not. Children don't need our help to think about sex ...There are groups of people out there who are devoted to scaring the heck out of Americans about sexuality ...It makes some people feel good because they say, 'Aha, there's the enemy and if only we could do something about that, everything would be better.' "{{cite web|last1=Stossel|first1=John|title=Sex, Sex Everywhere|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/Stossel/story?id=4400537&page=1|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=23 January 2017}} It's a parenting issue, Klein told NPR, when children are viewing something that is made for adults. Parents need to educate their children and increase their sexual literacy, so that they understand that what they are seeing on the Internet is fantasy.{{cite web|title=Moral Panic at Sex Tech|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KbLukTdduA|publisher=Sex Tech|accessdate=28 January 2017}} {{Cquote|The two best strategies for improving sex are better communication and more self-acceptance. ...Self-acceptance: your body is the way it is; you’re not going to lose 10 pounds this weekend. ... One breast is bigger than the other, one nipple has a few stray hairs, your penis is exactly the size it is. ...Vanilla sex isn’t what makes people bored. Focussing on distracting stuff does. Feeling disconnected does. Having sex when you’re resentful or too tired does. ...If you and your partner(s) enjoy some kink, or a different time/place/activity every time you have sex, by all means have a good time. Nothing wrong with that if it works for you. But for most people, wilder isn’t necessarily better. In fact, wilder actually pulls some people away from the connection and focus that can make sex enjoyable. For better sex, don’t diss vanilla—slow down and get to know it better.{{cite web|last1=Klein|first1=Marty|title=Vanilla Sex—Our Best Friend|url=https://www.martyklein.com/vanilla-sex/|website=MartyKlein.com|accessdate=22 January 2017}}}} [[File:Marty Klein "War on Sex" 4-11-2015 NECSS.jpg|thumb|[[NECSS]] 2015]] =="Sex addiction"== When the expression "sex addiction" was coined in the mid-1980s by [[Patrick Carnes]], Klein began to lecture and write against this idea. Klein believed then - and continues to believe - that the concept of "sex addiction" is primarily a set of moralistic judgements dressed up as clinical theory. He has written that the concept is a simplistic explanation of poor sexual decision-making that demonizes sexuality. He says it ignores the roles of culture, religion and the psychological means of sex for individuals while portraying sexual desires as dangerous, often unhealthy and in need of strict control channeled into the one proper form of sexual expression. Klein has reservations that sex-addiction exists and believes that an addiction movement whose agenda is based on false assumptions is harmful to patients and to society, namely: that sexual desires are dangerous, controlling, and not healthy, and that there is only one way to express sexuality. It is unknown, according to Klein, if the sex addiction movement realized that its ideas would become politically exploited. Regardless of their intentions, this is what activists, government and the media have done in order to discredit the profession of [[sexology]]. Issues such as culture, religion, age and disorders must be taken into account. He states that society needs to come up with "sex-positive" models of "sexual health". These models should reflect good education for children as well as for adults, while being sensitive across different cultures.{{cite web|last1=Klein|first1=Marty|title=Sex Addiction: A Dangerous Clinical Concept|url=http://www.siecus.org/_data/global/images/SIECUS%20Report%202/31-5.pdf|website=Siecus.org|publisher=Siecus Report|accessdate=22 January 2017}} Klein's concerns with the concept of sexual addiction are that it appears to lend scientific credibility to it and implies that "sex is dangerous."{{cite web|last1=Verghese|first1=Abraham|title=The Pathology of Sex|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1998/02/16/the-pathology-of-sex|website=Annals of Addiction|publisher=The New Yorker|accessdate=22 January 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Yeung|first1=Bernice|title=Sex and the Single Psychologist|url=https://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/sex-and-the-single-psychologist/Content?oid=2151348&showFullText=true|website=News|publisher=SF Weekly|accessdate=22 January 2017}} Twelve-step programs for sex addiction are of limited value because they are typically self-referred for a problem that any lay person can diagnose. There is no serious evaluation, just "Hello Joe, welcome to the group". Joe may suffer from other problems that will not be helped by a twelve-step program, and may in fact be made worse.{{cite web|title=Dr. Marty Klein, Marriage Counselor, Sex Therapist|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3w-_DtTecLM|publisher=You Tube|accessdate=22 January 2017}} Klein told [[NPR]] that the idea that going to strip clubs or "watching porn movies can actually be addictive in the same way that heroin is addictive is just silly."{{cite web|title=Dr. Marty Klein's NPR Response to Utah's "Porn Crisis"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UabOZlwPKmI|publisher=NPR|accessdate=28 January 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Savage|first1=Dan|title=Dan Savage Podcast: Porn Addiction|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mGIKjucEEgk|authorlink=Dan Savage|website=Dan Savage Podcast|accessdate=28 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Marty Klein|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-rrVoX-X7v8|publisher=Canadian TV Corp|accessdate=28 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Marty Klein|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IX35WJ545AY|publisher=Canadian TV Corp|accessdate=28 January 2017}} {{Cquote|There is no proof, no verified scientific data that people who look at pornography are more likely to commit violent or sexually deviant acts than anybody else... there is actually evidence to the reverse. Anti porn crusaders like to use the phrase "violent porn" as if it is one word. The good news is that most pornography is not violent. - Klein on ''[[Penn & Teller: Bullshit!]]''{{cite web|last1=Klein|first1=Marty|title=Episode 601 "War on Porn"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CVkoVTLuKN4|website=YouTube|publisher=Penn & Teller: Bullshit!|accessdate=22 January 2017}}}} ==Court cases== Michigan passed a law in 1999 criminalizing the distribution of "sexually explicit" material on the Internet fearing it could fall into the hands of minors. Plaintiffs, which included Marty Klein, challenged the law arguing that it violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments, and it was ruled unconstitutional in June 2001.{{cite web|title=Cyberspace Communications, Inc. v. Engler|url=http://mediacoalition.org/cyberspace-communications-v-engler/|website=Press Releases|publisher=The Media Coalition|accessdate=22 January 2017}} In April 2000 Arizona Governor [[Jane Hull]] signed law H.B. 2428 which added the Internet to the "harmful to minors" statute. Plaintiffs including Klein sought to have the Internet removed, claiming the law was far too broad contrary to the First Amendment. After reaching the [[9th Circuit]] in June 2002, the Court struck down the law as unconstitutional in ''American Civil Liberties Union v. Goddard''.{{cite web|title=American Civil Liberties Union v. Goddard|url=http://mediacoalition.org/aclu-v-goddard/|website=Press Releases|publisher=The Media Coalition|accessdate=22 January 2017}} {{cite web|title=Marty Klein|url=http://mediacoalition.org/?s=Marty+Klein|publisher=The Media Coalition|accessdate=22 January 2017}} In early 2010 an addition was proposed to Massachusetts Senate Bill 997 adding "electronic media" to traditional media in its "harmful to minors" law. This would have criminalized any material posted on the Internet that might be considered harmful if viewed by a minor. The plaintiffs argued that this could "potentially ban constitutionally protected speech about art, literature, sexual health and other topics." The case was heard in October 2010, and in April 2011 the Bill was signed into law, but with the stipulation that it could only be enforced if the "harmful material" was knowingly distributed to a minor. Marty Klein was the only individual among the various institutional plaintiffs.{{cite web|title=American Booksellers Foundation for Free Expression v. Coakley|url=http://mediacoalition.org/abffe-v-coakley/|website=Press Releases|publisher=Media Coalition|accessdate=22 January 2017}} According to lead attorney Michael Bamberger in 2010, the "harmful to minors" law is too broad and will harm adults that have a constitutional right to content on the Internet, '"(T)he injunction was necessary to ensure that all Internet communications were not reduced to the level of what is appropriate for children."'{{cite web|title=Press Release: Federal District Court Grants Preliminary Injunction Against Online Censorship Law|url=http://mediacoalition.org/press-release-abffe-coakley-massachusetts-preliminary-injunction/|website=Press Releases|publisher=The Media Coalition|accessdate=22 January 2017}} Plaintiffs were concerned that fines of up to $10,000 and five years in prison would have a chilling effect on booksellers as websites have no way to determine the age of an Internet user, and it is not possible to block only users located in Massachusetts. Thus the law would threaten Internet users nationwide and even worldwide.{{cite web|title=Press Release: Local Booksellers, National Trade Associations, ACLU, and Others Sue to Block Internet Censorship Law|url=http://mediacoalition.org/press-release-abffe-coakley-massachusetts-harmful-to-minors-internet-lawsuit/|website=Press Releases|publisher=The Media Coalition|accessdate=22 January 2017}} Klein has been an expert witness, consultant, or invited plaintiff in many state, federal, and international censorship, internet, and obscenity cases. ==Personal life== Klein is an extensive traveler and maintains a travel blog for his various trips, including India (2007), Azerbaijan (2009), Viet Nam (2010), Ukraine (2010), China (2011), Brazil (2011), Poland (2012), Myanmar (2013), Italy (2014), Hong Kong (2015), Japan (2015) and Greece (2016). All the photos on his blog are his own.{{cite web|last1=Klein|first1=Marty|title=Marty's Travel Blog: History, Culture, & People|url=https://martystravels.wordpress.com/|website=Marty's Travels|publisher=Wordpress|accessdate=28 January 2017}} ==Awards== Klein has been honored by the following professional associations: *American Association of Sexuality Educators, Counselors & Therapists: Sexuality Book of the Year *California Association of Marriage & Family Therapists Literary Achievement *Honorary Memberships : Croatian Society for Medical Hypnosis and the Slovenian Society for Hypnotherapy ==Select bibliography== ===Books=== Klein has authored seven books on sexuality. His book ''America's War on Sex'' with a forward by [[ACLU]] President Nadine Strosse was honored as 2006's Best Sexuality Book by [[AASECT]].{{cite web|title=Monday Reviews: America's War on Sex|url=http://thecsph.org/monday-reviews-americas-war-on-sex|publisher=CSPH|accessdate=22 January 2017}} It documents how the issue of sexual regulation is being used by the [[Religious Right]] to undermine secular democracy. Klein details what he describes as a well-coordinated, deeply funded war on sexuality which is being fought on many fronts. Klein explores what he sees as the U.S.'s deep-seated anxiety about sexuality and the lengths to which the U.S. government is willing to go to keep its citizens sexually repressed. Klein challenges American society's (and [[psychotherapy|psychotherapy's]]) assumptions about sexuality; he is particularly critical of what he calls the "Sexual Disaster Industry" and the "Oprah-ization" of psychotherapy and medicine.{{cite journal | url=http://www.ejhs.org/volume9/book38klein.htm | title=America's War On Sex | author=Kernes, Mark | journal=Electronic Journal of Human Sexuality |date=November 2006 | volume=9}} *{{cite book|last=Klein|first=Marty|title=Your Sexual Secrets: When to Keep Them, When & How to Tell|year=1988|publisher=Dutton|isbn=978-0525247166|author-mask=0}} *{{cite book|last=Klein|first=Marty|title=Ask Me ... Anything: Dr. Klein Answers the Sex Questions You'd Love to Ask|year=1996|publisher=Simon & Schuster/Fireside|isbn=978-0970452634|author-mask=0}} *{{cite book|title=Let Me Count the Ways: Discovering Great Sex Without Intercourse | publisher=Tarcher | last1=Klein | first1=Marty | last2 = Robbins |first2=Riki | year = 1999 | isbn=978-0874779561}} *{{cite book|title=Beyond Orgasm: Dare to Be Honest about the Sex You Really Want | publisher=Ten Speed Press | author=Klein, Marty | year=2002 | isbn=978-1587611681|author-mask=0}} *{{cite book|title=America's War on Sex: The Continuing Attack on Law, Lust, and Liberty | publisher=Praeger | author=Klein, Marty | year=2006 | isbn=978-1440801280|author-mask=0}} *{{cite book|last=Klein|first=Marty|title=Sexual Intelligence: What We Really Want from Sex - and How to Get It|year=2012|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0062098580|author-mask=0}} *{{cite book|last1=Klein|first1=Marty|title=His Porn, Her Pain: Confronting America's Porn Panic with Honest Talk about Sex|date=2016|publisher=Praeger|isbn=978-1440852213|author-mask=0}} ===Book chapters=== *Handbook of Clinical Child Psychology (1992, ed C.E. Walker, Wiley)Treating Sexual Disorders (1997, ed Randolph Charlton, Jossey-Bass) *Pornography: Film & Culture (2006, ed Peter Lehman, Rutgers University Press) *International Encyclopedia of Human Sexuality (2015, eds Patricia Whelehan & AnneBolin, Wiley-Blackwell) ===Other publications=== *''Contemporary Sexuality''{{cite web|title=Search Results for Marty Klein|url=http://cs.aasect.org/search/node/Marty%20Klein|publisher=Contemporary Sexuality|accessdate=22 January 2017}} *''The Humanist''{{cite web|title=Marty Klein, Sexual Intelligence|url=https://thehumanist.com/voices/sexual-intelligence/|website=Voices|accessdate=22 January 2017}} *''Psychology Today''{{cite web|title=Meet the Experts|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/experts/topics/sex|publisher=Psychology Today|accessdate=28 January 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|2573278}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zC2r9vdRxKo Marty Klein at Sara's Secret 2016] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UR2jZNllxwU The Aspen Institute - "The Importance of Porn Literacy: Adults, Teens, and Everyone Else" 2016] *[https://radiomd.com/player/item/15764-the-top-ways-to-make-sex-better-after-menopause#.WIwflBsrKUl Radio MD - Top Ways to Make Sex Better after Menopause] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UabOZlwPKmI National Public Radio: Utah Declares Porn a Public Health Crisis] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=to6cFe6op9s Commonwealth Club: Sexual Intelligence: A New View of Sexual Function & Satisfaction] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KbLukTdduA SexTech 2012: Sexuality + Youth + Technology = Panic] == Further reading == *[https://www.empowher.com/media/video/are-sex-toys-legitimate-part-womans-sex-life-dr-klein-video EmpowHER: Are Sex Toys for Women Legitimate? Do you Want More? If So, What?] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Klein, Marty}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American sex educators]] [[Category:American sex columnists]] [[Category:American relationships and sexuality writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Lecturers]] [[Category:1950 births]]

revision.comment: /* From 2001 */ Milroy Lecture 2017 Reference edited with [[Wikipedia:ProveIt|ProveIt]]
revision.text:
The '''Milroy Lectures''' are given on topics in [[public health]], to the [[Royal College of Physicians]], London. They were set up by money left by [[Gavin Milroy]], who died in 1886.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cats/8/7174.htm|title=AIM25 text-only browsing: Royal College of Physicians: ''Milroy, Gavin (1805-1886)''|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref>
==List of lectures== {{expand list|date=May 2016}}
===To 1900=== *1888 Robert Lawson, ''Epidemic Influences''<ref>Robert Lawson (1888) [https://archive.org/details/milroylectureson00laws ''The Milroy lectures on epidemic influences: On the epidemiological aspects of yellow fever: On the epidemiological aspects of cholera'']</ref> *1889 [[John Thomas Arlidge]], ''Hygiene, Diseases and Mortality of Occupations''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=57202|first=Clare|last=Holdsworth|title=Arlidge, John Thomas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/125|title=Munks Roll Details for John Thomas Arlidge|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1890 [[Arthur Ransome (physician)|Arthur Ransome]], ''The Causes and Prevention of Phthisis''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=57129|first=K. A.|last=Webb|title=Ransome, Arthur}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Arthur Ransome|title=The Causes and Prevention of Phthisis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A_E0AQAAMAAJ|year=1890|publisher=Smith, Elder}}</ref> *1891 [[Sir Richard Thorne]], ''Diphtheria: Its Natural History and Prevention''<ref>{{cite book|author=Epidemiological Society of London|title=Transactions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZMIDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA212|year=1790|publisher=Bogue|page=212}}</ref> *1892 Francis Warner, ''On an Inquiry as to the Physical and Mental Condition of School Children''<ref>{{cite book|author=Mark Jackson|title=The Borderland of Imbecility: Medicine, Society and the Fabrication of the Feeble Mind in Late Victorian and Edwardian England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eJ_nAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA45|year=2000|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-5456-3|page=45 note 36}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first1=Francis |last1=Warner |title=Abstracts Of The Milroy Lectures On An Inquiry As To The Physical And Mental Condition Of School Children |journal=The British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=1629 |year=1892 |pages=589–91 |jstor=20245529 }}</ref> *1893 [[Arthur Whitelegge]], ''On Changes of Type in Epidemic Diseases''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=38123|first=Steve|last=Sturdy|title=Whitelegge, Sir (Benjamin) Arthur}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first1=B. Arthur |last1=Whitelegge |year=1893 |title=The Milroy Lectures On Changes Of Type In Epidemic Diseases |journal=The British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=1678 |pages=393–6 |jstor=20223610 }}</ref> *1894 [[John Berry Haycraft]], ''Darwinism and Race Progress''<ref>{{cite book|author=David Boucher|title=The British Idealists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E4_MpkL6ue4C&pg=PA63|date=31 July 1997|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-45951-8|page=63 note k}}</ref> *1895 [[Arthur Newsholme]],<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=35220|first=John M.|last=Eyler|title=Newsholme, Sir Arthur}}</ref> ''The Natural History and Affinities of Rheumatic Fever'' *1896 Edward Cox Seaton, ''The Value of Isolation and its Difficulties''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3979|title=Munks Roll Details for Edward Cox Seaton|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1897 William Collingridge, ''On Quarantine''<ref>{{cite book|author=Tim Carter|title=Merchant Seamen's Health, 1860-1960: Medicine, Technology, Shipowners and the State in Britain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xxUABQAAQBAJ&pg=PA79|year=2014|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|isbn=978-1-84383-952-1|page=79 note 45}}</ref> *1898 [[Sydney Arthur Monckton Copeman]], ''On the Natural History of Vaccinia'',<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=20757816 |pmc=2411419 |year=1898 |author1=Copeman |first1=S. M. |title=The MILROY LECTURES on the NATURAL HISTORY of VACCINIA: Delivered at the Royal College of Physicians |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=1950 |pages=1245–50 }}</ref> book version''Vaccination, Its Natural History and Pathology''<ref>{{cite book|author=S. Monckton Copeman|title=Vaccination, Its Natural History and Pathology: Being the Milroy Lectures for 1898|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gHxhnQEACAAJ|year=1899}}</ref> *1899 [[George Vivian Poore]], ''The Earth in Relation to the Destruction and Preservation of Contagia''<ref>{{cite book|author=George Vivian Poore|title=The earth in relation to the preservation and destruction of contagia: being the Milroy lectures delivered at the Royal college of physicians in 1899, together with other papers on sanitation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uu0TAAAAIAAJ|year=1902|publisher=Longmans, Green, and co.}}</ref> *1900 Frederick Joseph Waldo, ''Summer Diarrhœa, with Special Regard to Causation and Prevention''<ref>{{cite book|author=Sir Arthur Newsholme|title=Fifty Years in Public Health (Routledge Revivals): A Personal Narrative with Comments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hyw-CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA357|date=24 July 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-44309-4|page=357}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Lectures At The Royal College Of Physicians Of London |journal=The British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=2044 |year=1900 |pages=532 |jstor=20263639 }}</ref>
===1901 to 1950=== *1901 John Frederick J. Sykes, ''On The Influence of the Dwelling upon Health''<ref>{{cite journal |first1=John F. J. |last1=Sykes |title=The Milroy Lectures On The Influence Of The Dwelling Upon Health |journal=The British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=2096 |year=1901 |pages=505–9 |jstor=20267533 }}</ref> *1902 [[William Henry Corfield (hygienist)|William Henry Corfield]], ''On the Etiology of Typhoid Fever and its Prevention<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=32569|first=Richard|last=Hankins|title=Corfield, William Henry}}</ref> *1903 Herbert Timbrell Bulstrode, ''On the Causes, Prevalence and Control of Pulmonary Tuberculosis''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(01)50625-X |title=The Milroy Lectures ON THE CAUSES, PREVALENCE, AND CONTROL OF PULMONARY TUBERCULOSIS |journal=The Lancet |volume=162 |issue=4169 |pages=206 |year=1903 }}</ref> *1904 William Williams, ''On Deaths in Childbed: A Preventable Mortality''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(01)47315-6 |title=The Milroy Lectures ON DEATHS IN CHILDBED: A PREVENTABLE MORTALITY |journal=The Lancet |volume=164 |issue=4218 |pages=4 |year=1904 }}</ref> *1905 [[Thomas Morison Legge]], ''On Industrial Anthrax''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=49286|first=P. W. J.|last=Bartripp|title=Legge, Sir Thomas Morison}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=James F Stark|title=The Making of Modern Anthrax, 1875–1920: Uniting Local, National and Global Histories of Disease|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z3lECgAAQBAJ&pg=PT215|date=6 October 2015|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-31866-8|page=215}}</ref> *1906 [[William Heaton Hamer]], ''Epidemic Disease in England: The Evidence of Variability and of Persistency of Type''<ref>{{cite book|author=William Heaton Hamer|title=The Milroy Lectures on Epidemic Disease in England: The Evidence of Variability and of Persistency of Type|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ap09AAAAIAAJ|year=1906|publisher=Bedford Press}}</ref> *1907 Leonard Rogers, ''On Kāla-azār''<ref>{{cite book|author=Leonard Rogers|title=Fevers in the Tropics: Their Clinical and Microscopical Differentiation, Including the Milroy Lectures on Kāla-azār|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dsNAAQAAMAAJ|year=1908|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3835|title=Munks Roll Details for Leonard (Sir) Rogers|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1908 [[John William Henry Eyre]], ''On melitensis septicaemia (Malta or Mediterranean Fever)''<ref>{{cite book|title=The Milroy Lectures on Melitensis Septicaemia (Malta Or Mediterranean Fever)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p0r0MAEACAAJ|year=1908|author1=Eyre|first1=J. W. H}}</ref> *1909 Richard Tanner Hewlett, ''On Disinfection and Disinfectants''<ref>{{cite book|author=W. J. O'Connor|title=British Physiologists 1885-1914: A Biographical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KrToAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA193|year=1991|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-3282-0|page=193}}</ref> *1910 Alexander Grant Russell Foulerton, ''The Streptotrichoses and Tuberculosis''<ref>{{cite book|author=Alexander Grant Russell Foulerton|title=The Streptotrichoses and Tuberculosis (being the Milroy lectures for 1910)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SVgXAQAAMAAJ|year=1910|publisher=J. Nisbet & co., ltd.}}</ref> *1911 [[Arthur Edwin Boycott]], ''On Ankylostoma infection''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=32008|first=Geoffrey L.|last=Asherson|title=Boycott, Arthur Edwin}}</ref> *1912 [[Francis Arthur Bainbridge]], ''On Paratyphoid Fever and Meat Poisoning''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=30537|first=E. M.|last=Tansey|title=Bainbridge, Francis Arthur}}</ref> *1913 [[Robert McCarrison]], ''On the Etiology of Endemic Goitre''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=34678|first=Andrew A. G.|last=Morrice|title=McCarrison, Sir Robert}}</ref> *1914 Frank Shufflebotham, ''On the Hygienic Aspects of the Coal-Mining Industry in the United Kingdom''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishmining.co.uk/486.html|title=Milroy Lecture 1914 - Scottish Mining Website|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1915 Edgar Leigh Collis, ''Industrial pneumonoconioses with special reference to dust phthisis'', published 1919<ref>{{cite book|author=Frank Smith|title=Industrial Applications of X-Ray Diffraction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NXcGdZqkbQcC&pg=PA467|date=22 September 1999|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-8247-1992-0|page=467}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Marvin I. Schwarz|author2=Talmadge E. King|title=Interstitial Lung Disease|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MHfnRWo-WtoC&pg=PA538|year=2010|publisher=PMPH-USA|isbn=978-1-60795-024-0|page=538}}</ref> *1916 Samson George Moore, ''Infantile Mortality and the Relative Practical Value of Measures Directed to Its Prevention''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(01)14695-7 |title=The Milroy Lectures ON INFANTILE MORTALITY AND THE RELATIVE PRACTICAL VALUE OF MEASURES DIRECTED TO ITS PREVENTION |journal=The Lancet |volume=187 |issue=4836 |pages=944 |year=1916 }}</ref> *1917 William James Howarth, ''Meat inspection: with special reference to the developments of recent years''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(01)52125-X |title=THE Milroy Lectures ON MEAT INSPECTION, WITH SPECIAL REFERENCE TO THE DEVELOPMENTS OF RECENT YEARS |journal=The Lancet |volume=190 |issue=4905 |pages=335 |year=1917 }}</ref> *1918 Henry Richard Kenwood, ''On the Teaching and Training in Hygiene: Some Criticisms and Suggestions''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(01)26442-3 |title=ABSTRACTS OF the Milroy Lectures ON THE TEACHING AND TRAINING IN HYGIENE: SOME CRITICISMS AND SUGGESTIONS |journal=The Lancet |volume=191 |issue=4941 |pages=663 |year=1918 |last1=Kenwood |first1=H }}</ref> *1919 John Christie McVail, ''Half a Century of Small-pox and Vaccination''<ref>{{cite book|author=Bazin Hervé|title=Histoire des vaccinations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YSwQBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA449|date=1 January 2008|publisher=John Libbey Eurotext|isbn=978-2-7420-1011-0|page=449}}</ref> *1920 Aldo Castellani, ''The higher Fungi in relation to Human Pathology''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(00)80882-X |title=Milroy Lectures ON THE HIGHER FUNGI IN RELATION TO HUMAN PATHOLOGY |journal=The Lancet |volume=195 |issue=5044 |pages=943 |year=1920 }}</ref> *1921 [[Martin Flack]], ''On Respiratory Efficiency in Relation to Health and Disease''<ref>{{cite book|author=W. J. Press|isbn=978-0-7190-3282-0|page=284}}</ref> *1922 [[Major Greenwood]], ''on the Influence of Industrial Employment upon General Health<ref>{{cite Health''<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(00)95404-7 |title=The Milroy Lectures [ABRIDGED] ON CANNED FOODS IN RELATION TO HEALTH |journal=The Lancet |volume=201 |issue=5194 |pages=527 <ref>{{cite journal|title= The Lancet|volume =205| issue =5298|date= 14 March 1925| pages= 532–538}}</ref> *1926 [[William Whiteman Carlton Topley]], ''Experimental Epidemiology in Mice''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=36537|first=Keith|last=Vernon|title=Topley, William Whiteman Carlton}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/6753|title=Munks Roll Details for William |title=Milroy Lectures On Health Hazards In The Cotton Industry |journal=The British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=3453 |pages=451–6 |jstor=25322794 }}</ref> *1928 Francis Albert Eley Crew, ''Genetical Aspects of Natural Immunity and Disease Resistance'' <ref name=roll/> *1929 James Graham Forbes, ''Diphtheria Immunisation''<ref>{{cite Rheumatic Diseases''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1782|title=Munks Roll Details for James Alison Glover|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1931 Sheldon Francis Dudley, ''On Lessons on Infectious Diseases in The Royal Navy''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1351|title=Munks Roll Details for Sheldon Francis (Sir) Dudley|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1932 Charles Cyril Okell, ''On haemolytic streptococci''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3370|title=Munks Roll Details for Charles Cyril Okell|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1933 Robert Cruickshank, ''on Pneumococcal infections'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1094|title=Munks Roll Details for Robert Cruickshank|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1934 [[George Seaton Buchanan]], ''International co-operation in public health''<ref>{{cite Buchanan|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1935 Eric Henry Rhys Harries, ''Infection and its Control in Children's Wards''<ref>{{cite Pilmonary Disease due to the Inhalation of Dust''<ref name= roll/> *1937 Philip Montague D'Arcy Hart, ''prevention of pulmonary tuberculosis among adults in England'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/5505|title=Munks Roll Details for Philip Montague D'Arcy Hart|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1938 Bernard Edward Schlesinger, ''Public Health Aspect of Heart Disease in Childhood'' <ref name= roll/> *1939 Donald Stewart, ''Industrial Medical Services In Great Britain: A Critical Survey'' <ref name= roll/> *1940 Ronald Edward Village Life in Peace and War''<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=35526|first=George|last=Pickering|title=Pickles, William Norman}}</ref><ref>{{cite the Mortality and Incidence of the Principal Infections which Cause Death or Disability in Childhood''<ref>{{cite journal |title=Thrombosis Of Central Retinal Vein |journal=The British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=4336 |year=1944 |pages=227 |jstor=20344524 }}</ref> *1945 Henry Stanley Banks, ''Meningococcosis: a protean disease''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/222|title=Munks Roll Details for Henry Stanley Banks|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1946 Hugh Edward Magee, ''Application of Nutrition to Public Health'' <ref name= roll/> *1947 Ronald Epey Lane, ''The care of the lead worker''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondonac.uk/Biography/Details/2632|title=Munks Roll Details for Ronald Epey Lane|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1948 Graham Selby Wilson, ''The Public Health laboratory Service'' <ref name = RCPL/> *1949 Marc Daniels, ''Tuberculosis in post-war Europe'' <ref name=RCPL>{{cite book|title=A History of the Royal College of Physicians of London, Volume 4|first=George Norman|last=Clark|page=1694}}</ref> *1950 [[Weldon Dalrymple-Champneys]], ''Undulant fever, a neglected problem''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1129|title=Munks Roll Details for Weldon Dalrymple-Champneys|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref>
===1951 to 2000=== *1951 John Constable Broom, ''Leptospirosis'' <ref name=RCPL/> *1952 Victor Henry Springett, ''An interpretation of statistical trends in tuberculosis'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/5892|title=Munks Roll Details for Victor Henry Springett|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> *1953 [[Richard Doll|W. Richard S. Doll]], ''Bronchial carcinoma, incidence and aetiology'' <ref name=RCPL/> *1954 D.A. Long, ''The pathogenesis of Rheumatic Fever''<ref name=RCPL/> *1955 James A. revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} [[File:National Centre for Early Music - geograph.org.uk - 1801250.jpg|thumb|right|The National Centre for Early Music]] [[File:National Centre for Early Music, York 2.jpg|thumb|upright|A performance at the centre]] The '''National Centre for Early Music''' is an educational resource for [[early music]] located in [[York]], England. It is based in the converted and extended, Grade I listed [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[Church (building)|church]] of [[St Margaret's Church, York|St Margaret, Walmgate]].<ref>{{NHLE|num=1256319|desc=Church of St Margaret|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref>
Designed by [[van Heyningen and Haward Architects]], the Centre was opened in April 2000. It was created, with the aid of a grant from the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] and partnership money from organisations such as [[English Heritage]].<ref name="EH">{{cite web | url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/grant-aided-properties/national-centre-for-early-music-st-margarets-church-yo1-9tl/ | title=National Centre for Early Music, St Margaret's Church | publisher=English Heritage | work=Grant-aided Places | accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> The buildings of the Centre include a performance space (in the former church) and facilities for conferences and other events and recordings. Historic [[keyboard instrument]]s are available for hire. The church building, which had been [[Redundant church|redundant]] for some years, was upgraded to meet the needs of varying types and size of performance as well as many alternative uses such as teaching, conferences and exhibitions.<ref>[http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/archive/1998/06/11/7968927.Dreaming_of_those_early_gates_/?ref=arc Dreaming of those early gates!] [[The Press (York)|''The Press'']]. 1998</ref> The roof has been rebuilt for enhanced acoustics, and there are baffles to allow the acoustics to be modified.
The annual [[York Early Music Festival]] is organised from the church and is administered through the York Early Music Foundation, a UK registered charity. During the rest of the year, the Foundation promotes an educational programme based at the National Centre: events include seminars, workshops and [[master class]]es. New music is also promoted, for example there is an annual Young Composers Award to encourage composers to work with early music groups.<ref name="ncem">{{cite web | url=http://www.ncem.co.uk/competitions/ | title=Competitions | publisher=National Centre for Early Music | accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Centre for Renaissance and Early Modern Studies]] *[[English Cornett and Sackbut Ensemble]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.ncem.co.uk/ NCEM website]

{{Infobox Organization | name = National Professional Agricultural Students Organization | image = | size = 100px | caption = | abbreviation = PAS | motto = "Uniting Education & Industry in Agriculture" | formation = 1980 | Founder = Ken Olcott | type = [[Youth organization]] | status = [[Curriculum|Inter-Curricular]] [[Non-profit organization]] | purpose = To provide individual growth, leadership and career preparation opportunities for professional agriculture students. | headquarters = [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | region_served = | membership = 1115
56 Chapters{{cite web |url=http://www.teamaged.org/council/index.php/ag-ed-organizations |title=The National Council for Agricultural Education – Team Ag Ed |publisher=Teamaged.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407151929/http://www.teamaged.org/council/index.php/ag-ed-organizations |archivedate=2012-04-07 |df= }} | language = | leader_title = Executive Director | leader_name = MaryKay Delvo | leader_title2 = National Advisor | leader_name2 = Dr. Steve A. Brown[http://www.teamaged.org/council/index.php/board-of-directors#20, Team AgEd Board Representatives : Retrieved 2009-16-12] | affiliations = [[National FFA Organization]], [[Consortium of Collegiate Agricultural Organizations]] | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.nationalpas.org/}} }} '''The National Professional Agricultural Student Organization''', regularly referred to as PAS, is a national organization associated with postsecondary institutions offering baccalaureate degrees, associate degrees, diplomas and/or certificates in agriculture/[[agribusiness]] and natural resources. PAS is one of the ten career and technical student organizations that has been approved by the [[United States Department of Education]] as an integral part of career and technical education also referred to as [[vocational education]].[http://www.ctesarasota.net/about_students.html#pas: Retrieved on 2009-12-15][http://www.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ovae/pi/cte/vso.html:Retrieved on 2009-12-15][http://doe.sd.gov/OCTE/docs/CTSO_postsecondary_FactSheets.pdf, South Dakota Department of Education, PDF, Career & Technical Education Organizations][http://doe.sd.gov/OCTE/docs/CTSO_postsecondary_FactSheets.pdf,TeamAgEd 2008 Annual Report: Retrieved on 2009-12-15] PAS is a member of the [[Consortium of Collegiate Agricultural Organizations]].[http://www.agconsortium.org/Help.aspx :Retrieved on 2009-12-15] PAS was originally organized for postsecondary programs awarding associate degrees or certificates and has since expanded to include baccalaureate degree programs.Career and Technical Student Organizations: A Reference Guide. Fiscus, Lyn et al. 2008[http://www.agedhq.org/agedorganizations.htm :Retrieved on 2009-12-15]National Center for Charitable Statistics, N.P.A.S.O. Retrieved on 2009-12-15 The Illinois PAS has all four of that state's agricultural universities involved in PAShttp://www.illinoispas.org/page/page/4327487.htm and Iowa PAS has their state land grant of [[Iowa State University]] in PAS.{{cite web|url=http://www.iowapas.org/history.aspx |title=History |publisher=Iowa PAS |date= |accessdate=2013-03-18}} This shift allows students who then transfer to a 4-year university to continue their direct involvement in PAS, provides the opportunities of PAS to university students and further deepens connections between 2 and 4 year agricultural institutions. The national organization was organized in March 1979 under Draft Bylaws. PAS was officially founded in March 1980 in Kansas City, Missouri.[http://www.iowapas.org/: Retrieved on 2009-12-15] == History == The history of PAS begins with the expansion of vocational-technical education at the postsecondary level. With state and federal legislation in the 60’s and 70’s, the agricultural education movement expanded greatly with more and more postsecondary agricultural programs. This movement started the creation of many local college student agricultural organizations at the two-year institutions. On the national level, the formation of PAS began with a National Seminar in 1966 at [[SUNY Cobleskill]], Cobleskill, New York. A Committee on “Youth Organizations and Activities for Two-Year Post High School Students in Agriculture" was created. It was decided that PAS should be separate from the [[National FFA Organization]]. It also recommended that the organizations begin first with the local, then state, and proceed to a national organization. Some states had developed equivalent organizations that proceeded the formation of the National PAS Organization. In Illinois, some 12 community college agriculture students, their advisors, and guests gathered on February 28, 1974, at the Illinois State Fairgrounds in Springfield for the purpose of forming a statewide organization. Copies of the Students With Agriculture Purposes (SWAP) Constitution and Bylaws were revised and developed into a state constitution and bylaws. Seeing the need for a different name for the organization, the Illinois Association of Community College Agriculturists (IACCA) was passed unanimously to replace SWAP. The IACCA Constitution and Bylaws were officially adopted on April 19, 1974. On February 25, 1989, at the 15th Annual Conference when the 16 delegates assembled voted to change the name from “IACCA” to “PAS” so that Illinois would be aligned with the National PAS Organization.http://www.illinoispas.org/page/page/4327237.htm The idea of a National Organization was again reviewed at the National Agricultural Education Seminar held in Muscatine, Iowa in 1969. However, there was not enough interest in forming a national organization at that time. In 1973 a National Standards conference hosted by the state of Minnesota recognized the potential need for a student organization. A NPASO Development Committee was formed and was to meet each year at the American Vocational Association (AVA) convention. In 1976 the committee held a brainstorming conference in the Quad Cities. Some of the major decisions included (1) the terminology of “Agriculture and Related Occupations for students enrolled in two-year institutions; (2) that the organization would be independent of the [[National FFA Organization]] and the FFA Alumni; and (3) the development of a procedure for funding and obtaining industry support. In 1977 with a grant from [[White Farm Equipment]] Company, an ad hoc committee met at the National FFA Center to develop the strategies for a national postsecondary student organization. The purpose was to verify the need for and feasibility of organizing an organization. In 1978, as a continuation of the [[White Farm Equipment]] Company grant, a National Seminar for Educators in Postsecondary Institutions was held in Kansas City, Missouri. The seminar concluded with acceptance of six reports including the acceptance and endorsement of the need for a National Postsecondary Student Organization for Agriculture/Agribusiness and Natural Resources students and the need to proceed immediately to finalize the organization.[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P3-1667923071.html, Western Illinois University Agriculture Education Major Elected Illinois Postsecondary Agriculture Student Vice President: Retrieved on 2009-12-15] The first national conference for the National Postsecondary Agricultural Student Organization was held in April 1979.http://www.iowapas.org == Membership == National PAS membership now totals some 1,115 members from 56 chapters located in 18 states. Membership is available to students in agriculture, agribusiness and natural resources postsecondary programs in approximately 550 institutions in all 50 states. == PAS Associates == PAS Associates is an organization of former members of the National Postsecondary Agriculture Students Organization. Advisors, administrators, industry representatives, parents, and other PAS supporters are also welcomed to become members. Despite a generally open membership the PAS Associates has had minimal activity and has been faced with financial issues. PAS Associates was officially organized at the 10th reunion National Conference in Kansas City, Mo., in March 1988.http://www.nationalpas.org:Retrieved on 2009-12-15 == Motto == Uniting Education & Industry in Agriculture[http://dese.mo.gov/divcareered/ag_postsecondary_student_org.htm: Retrieved on 2009-12-15][http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P3-327643141.html The Ag Education Magazine, Blecha, David, March 1, 2003. Retrieved on 2009-12-15]http://www.greatschools.net/LD/school-learning/CTSOs.gs?content=1003&print=true&fromPage=1,"Career and Technical Student Organizations: Extending Employment Preparation Beyond the Classroom" Evers, Rebecca: Retrieved on 2009-05-31 == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == *[http://www.nationalpas.org Official website] [[Category:Youth organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Agricultural organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Career and technical student organizations]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
'''NetDay''' (1995–2004) was an event established in 1995 that "called on high-tech companies to commit resources to schools, libraries, and clinics worldwide so that they could connect to the Internet".<ref name=established>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-9964131-54.html |title=Sun's John Gage joins Al Gore in clean-tech investing |accessdate= 2008-06-12 |author= |last= Olsen |first= Stephanie |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= June 9, 2008 |work= |publisher= }}</ref> It was developed by [[John Gage]] (then-chief science officer at [[Sun Microsystems]]) and activist Michael Kaufman. They approached Delaine Eastin, California's State Superintendent of Public Instruction, to put together the first event in California. <ref name=Clintonspeech>{{cite web|url=http://www.clintonfoundation.org/legacy/030996-speech-by-president-at-netday-concord-ca.htm |title=Remarks by the President to the Concord Community on NetDay: Ygnacio Valley High School, Concord, California |accessdate=2008-06-12 |author= |last=Clinton |first=Bill |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=Clinton Foundation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070512192539/http://www.clintonfoundation.org/legacy/030996-speech-by-president-at-netday-concord-ca.htm |archivedate=May 12, 2007 }}</ref> The first official NetDay was held in 1996.
In 2005, NetDay merged with'' Project Tomorrow'' (''tomorrow.org''), a California nonprofit involved with math and science education. The organization is continuing to work with schools to improve the use of technology in education.<ref name=ProjectTomorrow>{{cite web |url=http://www.tomorrow.org/speakup/speakup_congress.html |title= Project Tomorrow: NetDay |accessdate= 2008-06-12 |author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |vauthors= |date= |work= |publisher= }}</ref>
==Overview== NetDay was established to take place over the course of one Saturday, whereby designated schools would receive full connection to the [[Internet]]. Activities were coordinated at the website ''netday.org''. The HTML Writers Guild (quoting the NetDay FAQ) defined the day as an:
{{cquote|historic [[grassroots]] effort in the classic American [[barn-raising]] tradition. Using [[Volunteering|volunteer]] labor, our goal is to install all the basic wiring needed to make five classrooms and a library or a computer lab in every school Internet-ready. If the same work were financed by taxpayers, it would cost more than $1,000 per classroom. Volunteers from businesses, education, and the community will acquire all of the equipment and will install and test it at every school site. Your support and participation is crucial to our success. In addition, by bringing together these diverse elements, NetDay establishes a framework for lasting partnerships among business, government, educational institutions, and local communities to provide ongoing support for our schools.<ref name=writersguild>{{cite web |url=http://www.hwg.org/opcenter/events/netday.html |title= NetDay and the HWG |accessdate= 2008-06-12 |author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |vauthors= |date=September 12, 1998 |work= |publisher= }}</ref>}}
Some argued that access to the Internet should not be a priority when schools lack even basic resources like library books (although in many cases the project added needed materials and efforts to computing projects already underway).<ref>{{cite news|author=Laura Lindhe |title=SF State plugs into NetDay |url=http://www.journalism.sfsu.edu/www/pubs/gater/spring96/mar12/01.html |work=Golden Gater |publisher=[[San Francisco State University]] Department of Journalism |date=March 12, 1996 |accessdate=2008-06-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206025908/http://www.journalism.sfsu.edu/www/pubs/gater/spring96/mar12/01.html |archivedate=February 6, 2012 }}</ref>
==NetDay '96== [[Image:Phoc96v1.jpg|right|thumb|President [[Bill Clinton]] installing computer cables with Vice President [[Al Gore]] on NetDay at [[Ygnacio Valley High School]] in Concord, CA. March 9, 1996.]]
The first NetDay was held on March 9, 1996. NetDay '96 created considerable excitement amongst participating schools. The day was organized via the website ''netday96.com''. 20,000 volunteers helped to wire 20 percent of California schools to the Internet. 2,500 wiring kits were donated by telephone companies. Of the first event, John Gage commented, "NetDay96 is a demonstration of what can happen when people coalesce around a community project [...] In one day, we can begin to reverse California's abysmal record of putting technology into its classrooms."<ref name=chronicle>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/1996/03/09/MN59762.DTL |title=Clinton, Gore in Concord Today for NetDay: 20,000 volunteers wire computers at California schools |accessdate= 2008-06-12 |author= |last=Rubenstein |first=Steve |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=March 9, 1996 |work= |publisher= ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' }}</ref>
[[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]] and Vice President [[Al Gore]] were also involved with NetDay '96, spending the day at [[Ygnacio Valley High School]], as part of the drive to connect California public schools to the [[Internet]].<ref name=chronicle/> In a speech given at YVH, Clinton stated that he was excited to see that his challenge the previous September to "Californians to connect at least 20 percent of your schools to the [[Information Superhighway]] by the end of this school year" was met. Clinton also described this event as part of a time of "absolutely astonishing transformation; a moment of great possibility. All of you know that the information and technology explosion will offer to you and to the young people of the future more opportunities and challenges than any generation of Americans has ever seen".<ref name=Clintonspeech/> Clinton acknowledged the support of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction [[Delaine Eastin]], Lieutenant Governor [[Gray Davis]], Senator [[Barbara Boxer]] and Representative [[George Miller (California politician)|George Miller]].<ref name="Remarks on NetDay in Concord, California, March 9, 1996">{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yCThAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA403&lpg=PA403 |title=Public Papers of the Presidents of the United States: William J. Clinton, 1995; Remarks on NetDay in Concord, California, March 9, 1996 |author= |last=Clinton |first=William J. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1996 |work=Public Papers of the Presidents of the United States |publisher= }}</ref>
In a prepared statement, Gore added that NetDay was part of one of the major goals of the [[Clinton administration]], which was "to give every child in America access to high quality educational technology by the dawn of the new century." Gore also stated that the administration planned "to connect every classroom to the Internet by the year 2000".<ref name=Goreprepared>{{cite web |url=http://clinton4.nara.gov/WH/New/NetDay/Video/statement.html |title=Statement by the Vice President about Netday |accessdate= 2008-06-12 |author= |last=Gore |first= Al |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1997 |work= |publisher= }}</ref>
Another NetDay was held that same year in October in Silicon Valley, involving 80 companies and approximately 3500 volunteers helping to network 172 schools. The campaign was called Smart Schools NetDay II and was coordinated by Smart Valley, Inc., a [[501(c)_organization#501(c)(4)|501(c)(4) nonprofit organization]], part of the initiatives at Joint Venture: Silicon Valley.<ref>SmartSchools NetDay, www.svi.org/netday/, version November 27, 1996, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/19961127052934/http://svi.org/netday/ archive.org], accessed June 5, 2018</ref>
==NetDay Activities ==
On April 28, 1998, Gore honored numerous volunteers who had been involved with NetDay and "who helped connect students to the Internet in 700 of the poorest schools in the country" via "an interactive online session with children across the country."<ref name=honor>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_puca/is_199804/ai_1702147294 |title=GORE, RILEY AND KENNARD HONOR NETDAY VOLUNTEERS ANNOUNCE GUIDE TO ONLINE MENTORING, COMPUTER DONATIONS |accessdate= 2008-06-12 |author= Press Release |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=April 28, 1998 |work= US Education Department Press Releases |publisher= }}</ref> Volunteers continued to play a central role in NetDay school wiring activities, and by the end of 2001, NetDay events were held in 40 states and engaged more than 500,000 volunteers to wire more than 75,000 classrooms across the USA.<ref>About NetDay, netday.org/about.htm, version October 20, 2001, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20011020210501/http://www.netday.org/about.htm archive.org], accessed November 11, 2016</ref> Archived versions of the NetDay Web site, netday.org, say that NetDay events were planned for March 20, 1999,<ref>NetDay Home page, netday.org, version Feb 24 1999, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/19990224124742/http://www.netday.org/ archive.org], accessed November 11, 2016</ref> April 8, 2000,<ref>NetDay Home page, netday.org, version Apr 18, 2000, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20000418091053/http://netday.org/ archive.org], accessed November 11, 2016</ref> October 28, 2000,<ref>National School Wiring Day, netday.org/wiring.htm, version December 4, 2000, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20001204163200/http://netday.org/wiring.htm archive.org], accessed November 11, 2016</ref> March 31, 2001<ref>National School Wiring Day, netday.org/wiring.htm, version February 2, 2001, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20010202150000/http://netday.org/wiring.htm archive.org], accessed November 11, 2016</ref> and October 27, 2001.<ref>National School Wiring Day, netday.org/wiring.htm, version August 14, 2001, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20010814081044/http://www.netday.org/wiring.htm archive.org], accessed November 11, 2016</ref>
In its last four years of operation, NetDay changed its focus from one or two days a year to wire schools to the Internet. Its new events and activities included collaborating with [[Join Hands Day]] in 2002,<ref>Community Connection - Seasons of Service, netday.org/service_joinhands.htm, version December 2, 2002, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20021208103648/http://www.netday.org/service_joinhands.htm archive.org] on November 11, 2016</ref> and three new initiatives: NetDay TechDay,<ref>First Netday Techday Held In Mississippi Delta, netday.org/news_first_techday.htm, version October 3, 2003, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20031003190930/http://netday.org/news_first_techday.htm archive.org] on November 11, 2016</ref> NetDay Speakup Day<ref>NetDay Speak Up Day, netday.org/speakupday.htm archive.org, version October 3, 2003, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20031003201144/http://netday.org/speakupday.htm archive.org] on November 11, 2016</ref> and TESS - Technology Enhancing Student Success.<ref>TESS - Technology Enhancing Student Success, netday.org/comm_tess.htm, version October 3, 2003, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20031013212306/http://netday.org/comm_tess.htm archive.org] on November 11, 2016</ref>
In February 2006, NetDay merged with Project Tomorrow, a national education nonprofit organization.<ref>NetDay Home page, netday.org, version February 10, 2006, accessed at [https://web.archive.org/web/20060210062354/http://www.netday.org/ archive.org] on November 11, 2016</ref><ref>About Project Tomorrow [http://www.tomorrow.org/about/about_PT.html www.tomorrow.org/about/about_PT.html] accessed on November 11, 2016</ref>
